Wien Bridge Circuit

sidebyside.p: RC oscillators commonly use a Wein bridge circuit shown in . A galvanometer G is connected between the points marked A and B to detect any current flow between A and B. The Wein bridge circuit is said to be balanced when no current flows between A and B.

statement.p:
Prove that the following relations must hold true when the circuit is balanced.
\amp \frac{R_1}{R_2} + \frac{C_1}{C_2} = \frac{R_3}{R_4}, \amp \omega = \frac{1}{\sqrt{R_1 R_2 C_1 C_2}}.

hint.p: Replace passive elements by their complex impedances.

solution.p:
Let us replace the resistors and capacitors by their complex impedances. Suppose current I_1 flows in the upper branch and I_2 in the lower branch - note that the current through G is zero at the balance. Now, we write the Kirchhoff's loop rules for the loop on the left of the galvanometer G and the loop on the right of G for the condition that there be no current through G. This
\amp I_1 \left( R_1 - \dfrac{i}{\omega C_1} \right) = I_2 R_2, \amp I_1 \left[\dfrac{R_2\times \frac{-i}{\omega C_2}}{R_2 - \frac{i}{\omega C_2}} \right] = I_2 R_2.
Dividing out I_1 and I_2 gives the following complex equation.
\dfrac{(\omega R_1 C_1 -i)(\omega R_2 C_2 - i)}{-i\omega C_1 R_2} = \dfrac{R_3}{R_4}.
Separating out the real and imaginary parts of this equation gives
\amp \omega^2 R_1 C_1 R_2 C_2 -1 = 0, \amp \omega(R_1 C_1 + R_2 C_2) = \dfrac{R_3}{R_4}\:R_2 \omega C_2.
These equations yield the results we seek.

problem.title: Crossover Circuit

statement.p: A cross-over circuit is used deliver power to two different parts of the circuit depending on the frequency of the driving signal. For instance one would want more power be delivered to woofer at low frequency and to tweeter at high frequency.

sidebyside.p: For given L, C, R_1 and R_2 in the circtuin in , find the cross-over frequency such that below that frequency more power goes to R_2 and above that frequency more power goes to R_1.

solution.p:
Let Z_1 and Z_2 be the complex impedances of the upper and lower branches respectively.
\amp Z_1 = R_1 - \dfrac{i}{\omega C},\ \ |Z_1| = \sqrt{R_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{\omega^2 C^2}}, \amp Z_2 = R_2 - i \omega L,\ \ |Z_2| = \sqrt{R_2^2 + \omega^2 L^2}.
The amplitudes of the currents in the two branches will be
\amp I_{10} = \dfrac{V_0}{|Z_1|}, \amp I_{20} = \dfrac{V_0}{|Z_2|}.
Equating the power in the two resitors will give us a condition for the cross-over frequency \omega.
\dfrac{1}{2}I_{10}^2\:R_1 = \dfrac{1}{2}I_{20}^2\:R_2.
Therefore,
\dfrac{R_1}{|Z_1|^2} = \dfrac{R_2}{|Z_2|^2}.
This gives a quartic equation in \omega, which student is encouraged to solve. I found the following answer for the positive real \omega.
\omega = \amp \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}\;LC}\left[\left(R_1R_2 - R_2^2\right)C^2 + \sqrt{\left(R_2^2-R_1R_2\right)^2C^4 + \dfrac{4 R_2L^2C^2}{R_1}} \right].
